So let's talk about collective action.
I believe in Creative Commons believes that we should aspire to something greater than meticulously regulating monopolistic access for large rights holders.

The Commons is humanity's greatest collective act.

the Commons is a platform for sharing and collaborating, and it belongs to all of us, and it is a public good.
Now education is also a public good, at least it's supposed to be, but over the past 50 years I think we've lost our grip on this core value in education.
An educated child can overcome great challenges and find new opportunities to rise above their constraints of poverty or class structures.
An educated community can create prosperity, innovation and a diverse economy.
An educated citizenry elects just governments and is resilient in the face of misinformation propaganda and prejudice.
But in recent years, we've allowed that narrative to shift.
So that the primary beneficiary of education is seen to be the individual.
The ideal has allowed the kind of inequality and debt and exclusion that we see to see today to take root and to grow.
That kind of disparity that now requires SDG, four in the first place.
Today's educational business models contribute to that.
From this false belief in individual benefits taking precedence over investments in the public good.
If education was seen as a public good, we would ask ourselves how we should martial our collective wealth to ensure that it was accessible to everyone, not just those who could pay.
Today, trillions of dollars in public money are spent on grants to produce materials that we must purchase time and time again.

More recently, in response to these complaints about the high cost of materials publishers, instead, Lisa's DRM protected educational resource is so students lose actors access at some not so far into the future time.
The content is locked down in proprietary systems with no permissions for teachers to revise, localise, customize or translate to meet student needs.

Copyright with the public funds they've received.

The Copyright is held by the creator, and so depending on how you've enabled all of that sharing, you may have huge group of authors, each of whom holds individual Copyright.

And if they haven't shared under the terms that enable that, you have to ask them, and so you may need to find a way to go back and make sure that those works are licensed and then marked correctly so that anyone can use them.
So I think that's the fundamental piece, and So what we would recommend going forward is that you set that standard upfront.

When people enter into this idea with goodwill and the intention of sharing and collaborating.
